One of eleven forms of the སླར་བསྡུ་ concluding connector placed after the word that has an ending letter which is a re-suffixed ད་, even when the ད་ letter is not written in new orthography. E.g., འགྱུརད་ཏོ། is correct in old orthography and འགྱུར་ཏོ། is correct in new orthography because the actual ending of འགྱུར་ is a re-suffixed ད་ even though it is not visible.
to compose | to begin | to start

One of a group of three connectors ཅིང་, ཞིང་, and ཤིང་. They are ཕྲད་གཞན་དབང་ཅན་ dependent connectors. When one of them is required, this one is placed after names ending with ག་, ད་, བ་, and ད་དྲག་ "forceful da". They are non-case connectors. They function to show the end of a verbal phrase or clause in the middle of a sentence, and separate it from what follows. The connectors do not have a particular equivalent in English. Each instance has to be translated according to the context. However, they have the general meaning of "and" when separating two phrases/clauses or of "ing". Написать в

One of a group of three connectors ཅིང་, ཞིང་, and ཤིང་. They are ཕྲད་གཞན་དབང་ཅན་ dependent connectors. When one of them is required, this one is placed after names ending with ས. They are non-case connectors. They function to show the end of a verbal phrase or clause in the middle of a sentence, and separate it from what follows. The connectors do not have a particular equivalent in English. Each instance has to be translated according to the context. However, they have the general meaning of "and" when separating two phrases/clauses or of "ing". Написать в

One of a group of three terms ཅིག་, ཞིག་, and ཤིག་ that show the indefinite article. Placement: They are ཕྲད་གཞན་དབང་ཅན་ dependent connectors. When one of them is required, this one is placed after names ending with ག་, ད་, བ་, and ད་དྲག་ "forceful da". They are equivalent to the indefinite article "a" or "an" in English. E.g., ཕྲད་ཅིག་ "a connector"; རྒྱལ་ཁབ་ཅིག་ "a kingdom"; ཅུང་ཟད་ཅིག་ "a little bit". | One of a group of three terms ཅིག་, ཞིག་, and ཤིག་ that show the སྐུལ་ཚིག་ imperative. Placement: They are ཕྲད་གཞན་དབང་ཅན་ dependent connectors; when one of them is required, this one is placed after names ending with ག་, ད་, བ་, and ད་དྲག་ "forceful da". The connector can be either: 1) placed after a non-imperative verb form to make the imperative when the verb does not have an imperative form; 2) placed after an imperative verb form to secure the meaning of the imperative; or 3) placed at the end of a construct without a verb to make a verbal imperative. Within any of these constructions it is used either 1) to create the standard imperative or 2) the sense of "please do it" which is often best translated with "please" or "do this would you..." rather than the straight imperative.

A ཕྲད་གཞན་དབང་ཅན་ dependent connector which is one of the seven ལ་དོན་ "la-equivalents" q.v. for explanation. Placement: When a la-equivalent is required, either a specific one can be used according to the ending of the previous word (see དུ་, ར་, རུ་, སུ་, and ཏུ་) or this one or ན་ can be used in every situation except for the special case called ངོ་བོ་ "identity". As a la-equivalent, it is used to show three of the cases in Tibetan grammar. | It is used to indicate the མཚམས་སྦྱོར་ ending of phrases and clauses both when it shows མཚམས་སྦྱོར་ལྷག་བཅས་ continuation to further meaning to be connected with the preceding phrase or clause and when it simply shows the end of the phrase or clause in the larger context. In this usage, it is equivalent usually to a comma, full-stop, semi-colon or em-dash.

A ཕྲད་གཞན་དབང་ཅན་ dependent connector which is one of the seven ལ་དོན་ "la-equivalents" q.v. for explanation. Placement: When a la-equivalent is required, either a specific one can be used according to the ending of the previous word (see དུ་, ར་, རུ་, སུ་, and ཏུ་) or this one or ན་ can be used in every situation except for the special case called ངོ་བོ་ "identity". As a la-equivalent, it is used to show three of the cases in Tibetan grammar. | It is used to indicate the མཚམས་སྦྱོར་ ending of phrases and clauses both when it shows མཚམས་སྦྱོར་ལྷག་བཅས་ continuation to further meaning to be connected with the preceding phrase or clause and when it simply shows the end of the phrase or clause in the larger context. In this usage, it is equivalent usually to a comma, full-stop, semi-colon or em-dash.
